div.p:
Hic considerandum est Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 1, n. 1 . This is distinction 15 which connects to the procedding thus, for after the Master showed that the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father and the Son, now he inquires whether the Holy Spirit is able to give or send itself. And this is divided into three parts because he first shows that Holy Spirit sometimes sends itself, second he wishes to concludes this from the sending of the Son, third he asks whether we are now able to say that the Father has been sent. The second begins at
ne autem mireris Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 1, n. 5 . Third begins at
hic quaeritur, cur Pater Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 9, n. 1 . The first part remains undivided, but the second is divided into two because in the first place he shows that the beginning o the mission of the Son is manifold, in the second place he says that varied mode of this same mission. The second begins at
hic quaeritur, tantum semel Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 6, n. 1 . And this is the division in general of the first part of this distinction.

Hic quaeritur utrum semel tantum Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 6, n. 1 . This is the second principal part of this distinction, where after the Master concludes the mission of the Holy spirit from the mission of the Son, now he inquires about the manifold mission of the Son and divides into two because in the first place the Master shows there is a diverse mode of the mission of the Son, in the second place the Master concludes that the Father is not nor was not sent. The second is at
hic quaeritur cur Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 9, n. 1 . The first part stays undivided, but the second part is divided into two because in the first place the Master excludes every passive mission from the Father, in the second place regarding this is he recites one false opinion. The second begins at
ideoque putaverunt quidam haeretici Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 10 [n. 1]
etc. And this is the division in general and the opinion of the present distinction about which is currently under consideration.

Whether it ought to be admitted that any divine supposite is sent to any theologian; whether temporal mission of the Holy Spirit is a vital perception in the created mind; whether it is the case that the Holy Spirit is received from another and is in no way perceived by the one receiving it; whether it is the case that one receives the Holy Spirit and that same one having it in himself does not vitally perceive it.

It is argued thus because to receive is purely passive and to perceive is active, therefore one is able to stand without the other. The consequence holds because with respect to the same terms the created mind is not able at the same time to be purely passive and active, since perceiving is not formally
passive, and also because the perceptive power is universally more perfect than a passive power.

In the second place, if the question were true, it would follows that be fitting for any divine person to be perceived by the same one by whom it would be proper to be sent. The consequent is false because it appropriate for the Father to be perceived, and nevertheless it is not fitting for him to be sent, as is clear
in the penultimate chapter of this distinction Lombardus, Sent., I, d. 15, c. 9 [n. 1] . The consequence is clear because, if the sending and the perception are the same, it follows that to be perceived and to be sent are the same.

In the third place, if the question were true, it would follows that anyone existing in grace would perceive evidently. The consequent is he is worthy by love or hate. And the consequence is clear because to perceive something is to know it. In the second place, it follows that the newly baptized would have a mental perception of grace or of the Holy Spirit. In the third place, it follows that someone would receive grace as intense as they perceive it. The consequent is false because then the virgin would have had a more intense perception than someone, indeed than any angel, because she received more grace than any angel.

In opposition are the words of the present distinction in chapter 10 where he says,
tunc unicuique Spiritus Sanctus mittitur cum a quocumque cognoscitur atque percipitur quantum cognosci et percipi potest secundum capacitatem animae rationalis Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 7, n. 2 . Again,
in the same distinction in chapter 12 Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 7, n. 2 ,
when to be sent is said to be perceived by the mind from time
Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 20, n. 28 .

First conclusion: though the created intellective potency is in some way active with respect to some mission or vision of the divine, nevertheless no creature is able to be actively disposed, with respect to the expression of the uncreated word, through the mode of speaking. The first part is clear because in heaven the created intellective potency with respect to enjoyment is actively disposed. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is clear through the Decretals God bless our fruition stands or our formal beatitude consists in two acts of the because of the intellect and will which is the entire latitude of formal glory. The second part is clear because it follows that the uncreated Word would be a terminus produced from a created intellective power. The consequent is false, and the consequence is clear because it does not seem possible that the saying of anyone saying this is to speak a produced terminus of the same thing, and thus to speak would have a created uncreated terminus, which is false.

The first corollary: though the blessed soul is able to effectively concur with its own fruition, nevertheless it is not able to produce the light of glory in any mode. The first part is clear from the conclusion because such a light is producible by God alone.

The second corollary: though the created memory is able to be elevated beatifically through the divine essence as if an intellective species, nevertheless it is not the case that by this the uncreated Word is properly formed. This is clear because then the finite potency would produce an immeasurable term.
John of Marchia in his Determinations
Ripa, Determinationibus, Q. 3, a. 2, concl. 3
asserts the opposite of this corollary. The first part of is clear because God is able to supply two efficient causes in turn.

The third corollary: though the blessed soul is disposed passively with respect to fruition, nevertheless the same thing is able to be disposed actively with respect to cognition and delight. The first part is clear because it is receptive of these acts. The second part is clear through what is said in the conclusion and other corollaries.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p:
Second conclusion: though it is appropriate only for the Holy Spirit and the Son to be sent, nevertheless active mission is proper to each divine person. The first part is clear because to be sent is not appropriate for the Father, but it is for the Son and Holy Spirit. The first part of the antecedent is from
Augustine IV De Trinitate, in the last chapter
who says that the Father
is not said to be sent Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 20, n. 28 (PL 42:xxx) . The second part of the antecedent is clear through
Augustine II De Trinitate, chapter 5 saying
the Son was not able to be sent by the Father without the Holy Spirit, for the Father is understood as the one who sent him
because he was made the feminine because he certainly did not make him without the Holy Spirit
Augustinus, De Trinitate, II, c. 5, 8 (PL42:xxx) . But that the Holy Spirit was sent through the same one is clear through
Augustine in book IV De Trinitate, in chapter 19 , where he says expressly that
The Holy Spirit gives and sends itself Augustinus, XXX . Again John 15
I am sending you the spirit of truth Ioannes 15:26 . The second part is proved because the external work of the Trinity is undivided, but to send some person, etc., therefore. This is the argument of the
Master in distinction 15 Lombard, I, d. 15, XXX .

First corollary: it is not more repugnant for the Son to be sent by the Spirit that it is for the Son to be the spirator of the Holy Spirit. This is clear from what has been said because from each is true and not repugnant.
The second corollary: it ought to be admitted that it is appropriate for each person that the same thing is sent and sends itself. This is clear because to send is to act externally.

Third corollary: there is not perception of every divine person under a bodily likeness and to this same person there is passive mission. This is clear because the Father is not sent, and nevertheless appeared under a bodily likeness in the transfiguration when his voice was heard saying
Here is my beloved son Matthaeus 17:5; Lucas 15:24, Marcus 9:6 . From what has been said it is clear that to be sent is not merely absolute, but also convey a respect to some origin. This is clear because, if it were merely absolute, then it would be able to suit the Son and the Holy Spirit. Whence
Augustine IV De Trinitate, in chapter 30
says,
that the Son is sent is to know that it is from another
Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 20, n. 29 (PL 42:xx)

Third conclusion: though it is not the case that the Holy Spirit is received from something and that it is no way perceived by the one receiving it, nevertheless according to the common law non one is able to knowing perceive that he loves God meritoriously. The first part is clear because temporal sending of the Holy Spirit is a vital perception in the created mind, therefore. The antecedent is from the saying of Augustine introduced above in which it is said
the sending is said to be when the Holy Spirit is perceived by the mind from time Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 20, n. 28 . The second part is clear through the saying of the
Apostle I Corinthians 13
Nothing is known to me, but I am not in this justified
I Corinthians 4:4 . Again
John, in chapter 3
The Spirit breathes where he wills but you will not know from where it comes John 3:8
or the conclusion advances. Again, the negation is whether hate, etc.

The first corollary: while the law stand, though no one is able to know that they have ordinate love, nevertheless someone ought to believe that they have the sending of the Holy Spirit. The first is clear from what has been said. The second is proved because someone ought to believe that they have charity, therefore. The consequence holds because for the Holy Spirit to be sent into the mind is for charity to be infused in the mind, as the conclusion says. And the antecedent is clear from an adult approaching a sacrament by which grace is conferred, just as in the case of baptism and the eucharist.

The second corollary: it is not the case that the fruit of the divine mission increases in the mind and the vital perception of God is not intensified in the same thing. This is clear because, if not, if follows that not everyone receiving a sending of the divine person would have this vital perception, which is against the conclusion.

The third corollary: we do not always understand knowing uniformily. This is clear because otherwise one having such a perception would have evidence and experiential cognition, which is against what has been said. From what has been said the response is clear that it stands that some, etc.

div.head: Obiectiones et responsiones
div.p: Contra primam conclusio, sequitur quod memoria creata posset concurrere per suum posse essentiale active ad claritatem luminis gloriae. Consequens est falsum. Probatur consequentia quia non plus potest intelligentia creata ad dispositionem supernaturale et unionem vitalem divinae essentiae quam ad lumen gloriae.
Secundo, contra primum corollarium repugnat potentiam naturalem supernaturaliter agere per suum essentiale posse ergo repugnat intellectum creatum ad fruitionem prie[?] effective concurrere.

Tertio, contra secundum corollarium intelligentia creata concurrit effective ad motum visionis quo verum increatum redditur praesens vitari tali intelligentiae, sed hoc est verbum increatum dicere, ergo.

Contra tertium corollarium,
sequitur quod perfectiori in naturalibus semper correspondebit caeteris paribus intentior beatitudo, et per consequens stante aequalitate meritorum stabit inaequalitas primorum propter priora essentialia quod est falsum. Et patet consequentia quia puriora essentialia plus possunt quam minus pura et imperfecta.

Contra secundam conclusionem mitti et mittere sunt correlativa ergo cum mitti cogo?tet[?] respectum originis sequitur quod mittere dicit eundum respectum sed Spiritus Sanctus nihil originat adintra, ergo nullam personam potest mittere. Consequentia patet quia secundum Augustinum mitti est originari igitur mittere est originare.

Secundo, quia ille respectus quem[?] dicit mitti vel erit ad eum quam sit missio, et tunc erit communis tribus personis et sic Pater mittetur. Consequentia patet quia est respectus rationis adextra vel dicit respectum ad ipsum intentem et si sic vel ergo erit rationis tantum et tunc poterit esse in patre vel realis et tunc etiam mittere non erit essentiale, et per consequens non commune tribus personis quod repugnat secundae parti illius conclusionis.
Tertio mitti dicit respectum originis, ergo nulla persona potest se ipsam mittere. Patet consequentia quia nulla potest se ipsam originare.

Quarto mitti dicit imperfectam et indignitatem ergo nulli personae divinae competit. Consequentia bona sed antecedens probatur quia secundum
Dionysium in De angelica hierarchia Dionysius, De angelica hierarchia
angeli superiores semper assistunt Deo et non mittuntur propter sui dignitatem sed persona divina est improportionaliter dignior omni angelo, ergo propter sui dignitatem non debet mitti.

Contra tertiam conclusionem aliquis potest scire se esse dignum vita aeterna ego aliquis potest scire se Deum meritorie diligere saltim habitualiter. Consequentia bona et antecedens probatur quia aliquis potest scire se habere timorem filialem, ergo et caritatem. Consequentia tenet per glosam super illo primae Iohannis
perfecta caritas foras mittit timorem Glossa Ordinaria, xxx . Antecedens patet Genesis 22
cognovi quia timeas dominum, Genesis 22:12
id est cognoscere te feci. Item Philippenses 2o
petitiones vestrae innotescant apud deum Phil. 4:6 .

Item quis potest scire se omnia propter Deum diligere et omnia reliquisse, ergo scire se esse dignum vita aeterna consequentia tenet
Magister 19 Lombardus, XXX
omnis qui reliquer[?] etc. vitam aeternam possidebit.

Item, aliquis potest scire nullum timorem servilem se habere, ergo potest scire se habere caritatem. Consequentia tenet per illud primae Ioannes 4o
perfecta caritas, I Ioannes 4:18
etc.

Contra primum corollarium, nullus articulus cogit aliquem credere se esse in caritate, ergo. Antecedens patet quia si aliquis esset inderetur[?] ille credo instantiam[?] ecclesiam catholicam sed hoc non quia ecclesia nullibi hoc praecipit, immo videtur hypocrisis iudicare se in caritate, immo iudicare se esse extra caritatem videtur meritorium, ut patet de publicano luce 18.

Secundo, contra secundum corollarium peccator tenetur conteri de peccato ergo tenetur credere se esse in caritate et ultra omnis adultus vel est in caritate vel extra, ergo omnis tenetur se credere esse in caritate quod est primum
contra alia corollaria omnis perceptio est cognitio aliqualis et ad intentionem perceptionis sequitur intensio cognitionis, ergo illa corollaria falsa.

Ad primum, negatur consequentia et dicitur ad probationem quod non omnis missio personae divinae est supernaturalis dispositio ut praetendit argumentum loqui de dispositione. Secundo, posset antecedens negari antecedens generaliter. Tertio, posset concedi consequentia, iam negata, scilicet quod memoria etc non quid[?] agendo ipsum in ipso et circa ipsum.

Ad secundum, dicitur quod antecedens est verum si per suum naturale posse praecise non repugnat
ipsum sic agere cum adiunctione alterius potentiae modo in proposito non est solum naturale agens sed etiam supernaturale elevans potentiam seu ipsum posse naturale et actuans ipsum ad agendum.
Ad tertium, negatur minor quia ad talem motum concurrere non est dicere verbum incarnatum.

Ad quartum, dicitur primo negando consequentiam quia ad intensionem causae partialis non semper intenditur effectus actionis. Secundo, posset dici quod non secundum proportionem meritorum stabit retributio primorum quia tunc nullum primum daretur pro gratia baptismali quod est falsum. Tertio, posset concedi consequens dei tamen voluntate concurrente quae potest distribuere[?] praemia prout sibi placet.

Ad primum contra secundam conclusio distinguitur de mittere[?] quia uno modo accipitur principaliter auctorative, alio modo consequenter determinative. Primo modo tantum convenit Patri et Filio, secundo modo tribus. Ideo, si antecedens sumitur primo modo conceditur, si secundo modo negatur consequentia nec antecedens est verum.

Ad secundum, dicitur quod mitti dicit respectum non quid[?] ad mittentem determinative consequenter sed auctoritative principaliter. Similiter posset dici de mittere quod, si sumitur auctoritative, tunc nulla persona se ipsam mittit nec aliam nisi illam quam producit, sed bene 2o modo patet.

Hoc patet ad tertium argumentum,
vide de hoc Thomam Argentis Thomas de Argentina .

Ad quartum dicitur quod alias[?] est verum in creatura quia cum creatura mitti mutatur et movetur alicubi ubi prius non erat, sed quia Deus est ubique, ideo sine mutatione et imperfectione mitti potest divina persona quia non mittitur ubi non erat sed qualiter non erat novum effectum, scilicet causans in creatura sine sui mutatione, non tamen sine mutatione creaturae.

Ad primum contra tertiam conclusionem, negatur antecedens et ad probationem dicitur loquendo de timore formato caritate. Negatur illud et ad probationem dicendum quod illud cognovit Abraham ex divina revelatione sibi illud indicante et ad aliam probationem
petitiones vestrae Phil. 4:6
etc., dicitur quod ex Glossa non habetur nisi quod in aliquibus credimus nos a Deo esse ex auditos et forte scimus effectum operatum evenisse, sed ex hoc non sequitur contra conclusionem.
Ad aliud, negatur consequentia quia non ex operibus iustificatur quia Socrates divitias contempsit secundum Ieromum et tamen non iustificatus est.
Item ad aliud negatur consequentia quia ex puris naturalibus potest aliquis nullum timorem habere.

Ad primum contra corollarium, negatur antecedens quia continetur sub praeno?to[?] articulo vel quod idem est ille articulus dicit etiam hoc ecclesia dicit de accipientibus sacramentum eucharistiae ut patet Ad Corinthios 2o
probet autem se ipsum homo I Corinthios 11:28
etc. et hoc potest fieri sine hypocrisi et iactantia.
Ad tertium, conceditur consequentia et consequens, et negatur ulterior consequentia, sed bene sequitur quod tenetur esse in tali statu in quo credat se esse in caritate contra Monachum Nigrum.

Ad quartum, posset concedi consequens de cogitatione habituali non actuali de qua loquor in conclusione et corollario. Item, posset dici quod talis cognitio intenditur non tamen inesse cognitionis, sed solum inesse experimentalis perceptionis. Ex dictis patet.

Hic considerandum est Lombardus, I, d. 15, c. 1, n. 1 . Haec distinctio continetur 7 conclusiones. Prima: quod Spiritus Sanctus est Deus et donum, et ideo dat et datur: dat inquantum Deus, datur inquantum donum, nec ex hoc est minor Patre vel Filio.

Secunda conclusio: si Spiritus Sanctus non posset dare se ipsum Pater et Filius aliquid posset quod non posset Spiritus Sanctus et aliquid operarentur Pater et Filius quod non operaretur Spiritus Sanctus quae sunt inconvenientia quia opera Trinitatis adextra
sunt indivisa, ergo sequitur quod Spiritus Sanctus procedit temporaliter mittatur et datur a se ipso.

Tertia conclusio: quod potest numquam legitur missus sed solum Filius et Spiritus Sanctus Filius autem mti?tur[?] a Patre et se ipso et a Spiritu Sancto et illa missio fuit incarnatio quod fuit opus commune tribus personis.

Quarta conclusio quod cum Filius dicit Iohannis 8
a me ipso non veni Ioannes 7:28
hoc dictum fuit secundum formam servi secundum quam non est operatus incarnationem sed secundum formam Dei.

Quinta conclusio: Filius Dei praeter aeterna genitura secundum quam missus dicitur sed melius et verius secundum eam dicitur genitus duobus modis mitti dicitur vel cum visibiliter mundo apparuit in carne vel invisibiliter in animas pias transfert ut ab eis percipiatur et cognoscatur, primo modo semel est missus, secundo modo mittitur omnidie[?] non ut sit homo sed ut sit cum homine.
Sexta conclusio: licet Pater ex tempore cognoscatur sicut Filius, non tamen dicitur missus quia in Patre est auctoritas principii quia est principium Filii et Spiritus Sancti et non habet a quo sit.

Septima conclusio: Pater non ideo dicitur misisse Filium et Spiritum Sanctum quia ille maior est et illi minores sicut quidam haeretici putarunt sed propter comm?di[?] auctoritatem principii et quia Pater non apparuit in creatura visibili sicut Filius et Spiritus Sanctus quia tantum in voce quae non est visibilis sed audibilis, etc.
